ARCHIVIST (CONT’D) 
A camera swivelled to focus on her the moment she left her flat, stepping onto 
the landing, lens extending towards her, right at eye level. She instinctively 
swatted at it, batting it away. 
[Wet crunching impact] 
ARCHIVIST (CONT’D) 
It was softer than she expected, and warmer, impacting the wall with a gentle 
pop, and leaving a sticky grey residue behind it. Carmen hurried down the 
stairs as the other cameras all focused on her, and the other doors on the floor 
began to open to see what all the fuss was about. 
[Hurried footsteps on concrete; cameras iris, doors creak open] 

The Magnus Archives – MAG 188 – Centre of Attention 
 
16 
ARCHIVIST (CONT’D) 
From the speed at which they opened, her neighbours must have been 
standing just behind them. Waiting. 
She took it two steps at a time going down, and almost tripped and fell twice, 
but it was better than the lift. The lift was nothing but cameras and mirrors, 
infinite reflections staring at each other out to all eternity and the endless 
multiplication of four cameras to watch it all forever. No, she wasn’t going in 
the lift. 
[Transitions to exterior door opening to urban London sounds 
including people talking] 
[Footsteps as she walks] 
ARCHIVIST (CONT’D) 
At last she was in the street, the air of the city close, dry and tinged with that 
gritty texture that always made her afraid she was going to have an asthma 
attack. Did she have one recently? There were memories, flashes of lying on 
the ground, desperate for someone, anyone, to help. But they had just 
watched silently. Some had taken videos. But she was here now, and she 
couldn’t afford to have another attack today. She had somewhere very 
important to be. 
The street outside was not crowded, which gave Carmen the briefest moment 
of hope. Perhaps she could make her journey in relative peace. 
[A camera iris, followed by two synchronised footsteps as 
people turn; crowd talking stops, whispers start] 

The Magnus Archives – MAG 188 – Centre of Attention 
 
17 
ARCHIVIST (CONT’D) 
But then the camera orb on a nearby pole swivelled to focus on her and, just 
like that, every single person turned towards her as one. Her stomach dropped 
as one by one their faces lit up, taking on that unmistakable hue of 
anticipation; of recognition. Carmen could remember none of these people, 
but there was no ignoring the fact that they definitely knew her and, more 
than that, she was important to them. 
‘Oh my god,’ a young man said as she tried to walk past him, ‘it’s you!’ 
[Carmen’s walking stops] 
ARCHIVIST (CONT’D) 
He waited for a response, but Carmen had nothing to say, and as her feet 
locked in place her mind could do nothing but recite at her a litany of her 
inadequacies, her failures, her regrets. What did he want from her? His smile 
turned into a sneer. 
‘I should have known,’ he spat, ‘what a disappointment.’ 
[Carmen’s walking restarts] 
ARCHIVIST (CONT’D) 
Carmen tried to walk faster, ignoring the middle-aged woman who looked her 
up and down, not bothering to hide the judgement in her gaze. All she had to 
say was, ‘Oh.’ 
A little girl implored for Carmen to play with her, huge eyes pleading, but she 
didn’t have time.
